name: Aboriginal History Archive
description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

key_work.title: Aboriginal History Archive
key_work.brief_description: The Aboriginal History Archive is Australia’s first collection of resources that documents the Black Power movement, resists colonial narratives and celebrates self-determination. Activists of the era saw the power of film and TV to tell truth, advocate for justice and resist oppression.

constellations_primary.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_primary.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

start.title: Backroads
start.brief_description: Phillip Noyce’s Backroads (1977), made in close consultation with Gary Foley, was groundbreaking for tackling racism and giving First Peoples a say in how they were portrayed.

constellations_other.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

end.title: Dogs in Space
end.brief_description: Melbourne, Australia 1978. The punk phenomenon is sweeping the country and Dogs In Space, a punk group, are part of it. A ragtag collection of outcasts live in a squat, surviving on a diet of old TV space films, drugs and good music.

constellations_other.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

constellations_other.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_other.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but their scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

links.description: Gary Foley later appeared in Dogs in Space (1986), Richard Lowenstein’s cult classic film about Melbourne’s post-punk music scene in the late 1970s, starring Michael Hutchence of INXS fame.

start.title: The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith
start.creator_credit: Fred Schepisi, Bruce Finlayson, The Film House, Victorian Film and Wendy Dickson

video_links.name: The Chant Of Jimmie Blacksmith Trailer

start.brief_description: In the late 1970s, non-Indigenous filmmakers wanting to support Indigenous Rights in Australia released films on Black Australia to mixed success. Fred Schepisi’s controversial The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith (1978) divided audiences and demonstrated how non-Indigenous storytellers could co-opt Indigenous stories to great detriment.

constellations_other.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

constellations_other.name: Controversy and censorship
constellations_other.description: In this constellation, we look at the history of censorship in moving image history, from early blaxploitation films to videogames and beyond.

end.title: Wrong Kind of Black
end.brief_description: From the cops and the crocs of 1960s Palm Island to the blood-spattered dance floors of Melbourne in the 70s, Wrong Kind of Black is the personal story of Boori Monty Pryor (Clarence Ryan) and his brother Paul (Aaron McGrath).

constellations_other.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

constellations_other.name: Laughing in the face of adversity
constellations_other.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

links.description: Tom E Lewis also appeared in the TV series Wrong Kind of Black (2018), a comedy-drama about an Aboriginal DJ in Melbourne’s disco scene of the 1970s, narrated by and based on the life of author Boori Monty Pryor.

end.title: Kiki and Kitty
end.brief_description: Kiki and Kitty follows the adventures of a young, black woman in a big, white world, where her vagina is a big, black woman AND her best friend.

constellations_other.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

constellations_other.name: Sequins and sapphires
constellations_other.description: Two of the most striking costumes on the big and small screens embody the glamour of leading First Peoples ladies.

constellations_other.name: Laughing in the face of adversity
constellations_other.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

links.description: Lisa Flanagan also appears in comedy series Kiki and Kitty, which was written by and stars Nakkiah Lui as Kiki.

start.title: Kiki and Kitty
start.brief_description: Kiki and Kitty follows the adventures of a young, black woman in a big, white world, where her vagina is a big, black woman AND her best friend.

end.title: Black Comedy
end.brief_description: Black Comedy is irreverent, politically incorrect and goes where no other series can go. Featuring a fantastic ensemble cast of Indigenous writers and performers, including many special cameo appearances.

constellations_other.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

constellations_other.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

constellations_other.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_other.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

links.description: Nakkiah Lui is also a writer and star of ABC sketch comedy series Black Comedy, which follows in the tradition of Basically Black, starring Gary Foley and Bob Maza and based on the theatre production of the same name.

end.title: The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith
end.creator_credit: Fred Schepisi, Bruce Finlayson, The Film House, Victorian Film and Wendy Dickson

video_links.name: The Chant Of Jimmie Blacksmith Trailer

end.brief_description: In the late 1970s, non-Indigenous filmmakers wanting to support Indigenous Rights in Australia released films on Black Australia to mixed success. Fred Schepisi’s controversial The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith (1978) divided audiences and demonstrated how non-Indigenous storytellers could co-opt Indigenous stories to great detriment.

constellations_other.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

constellations_other.name: Controversy and censorship
constellations_other.description: In this constellation, we look at the history of censorship in moving image history, from early blaxploitation films to videogames and beyond.

links.description: The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith (1978) starred Tom E Lewis in his first acting role, as the titular character. Unlike Backroads, the film was controversial for its portrayal of Aboriginal people and culture.

start.title: Aboriginal History Archive
start.brief_description: The Aboriginal History Archive is Australia’s first collection of resources that documents the Black Power movement, resists colonial narratives and celebrates self-determination. Activists of the era saw the power of film and TV to tell truth, advocate for justice and resist oppression.

constellations_primary.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

end.title: Backroads
end.brief_description: Phillip Noyce’s Backroads (1977), made in close consultation with Gary Foley, was groundbreaking for tackling racism and giving First Peoples a say in how they were portrayed.

constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

links.description: The road movie Backroads (1977) was directed by Phillip Noyce and features Gary Foley alongside Bill Hunter and Zac Martin. Foley was heavily involved in determining the film’s portrayal of Aboriginal characters and experience.

start.title: Wrong Kind of Black
start.brief_description: From the cops and the crocs of 1960s Palm Island to the blood-spattered dance floors of Melbourne in the 70s, Wrong Kind of Black is the personal story of Boori Monty Pryor (Clarence Ryan) and his brother Paul (Aaron McGrath).

The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

constellations_other.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

end.title: Redfern Now

video_links.name: Redfern Now | Starts 8.30pm on Thursday, 1 Nov 2012, ABC1

end.brief_description: Redfern Now is a kaleidoscopic drama that explores this inner-city suburb and the people who inhabit it. The highly celebrated and multi award-winning drama series written, directed and produced by Indigenous creatives.

constellations_other.name: Jedda: Uneven ground, the road to on-screen diversity
constellations_other.description: Jedda was the first fully funded Australian feature to be shot on colour film. It was also the first Australian film with Aboriginal actors in lead roles, however, it reflects a deeply problematic time in Australian history.

constellations_other.name: The secret life of suburbia and music videos
constellations_other.description: Australia's famous streets and suburbs have defined music videos, TV shows and miniseries, providing a unique backdrop to Australian stories and music.

constellations_other.name: Landscape as Character
constellations_other.description: The landscape is often a character in Australian films. Usually, it's a villain that represents our problematic national character and is increasingly used to challenge our troubled history and explore our evolving identities.

constellations_other.name: Canopy
constellations_other.description: John Harvey is a Torres Strait Islander producer, director and writer in screen and stage whose work Canopy celebrates Indigenous self-representation.

constellations_other.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

links.description: Lisa Flanagan appeared alongside Tom E. Lewis in Wrong Kind of Black (2018) and is well known for her roles on Australian screen, including in Redfern Now (2012–15), following the lives of contemporary Aboriginal Australians in the Sydney suburb of Redfern.
